q: What are some common symptoms of STIs?
a: Common symptoms of STIs include an unusual discharge, pain when peeing, lumps or skin growths, rashes, itching, blisters and sores, and warts.

q: When should I go to a sexual health clinic?
a: You should go to a sexual health clinic if you have symptoms of an STI, if your sexual partner has symptoms, if you're worried after having unprotected sex, or if you're pregnant and have symptoms of an STI.

q: Why should I go to a sexual health clinic?
a: You should go to a sexual health clinic because they specialize in treating STIs, you can usually get quicker test results, you may not have to pay a prescription fee, and you can feel comfortable discussing your sexual activities and orientation.

q: What happens at a sexual health clinic?
a: At a sexual health clinic, a doctor or nurse will ask you questions about your sex life, may perform a physical examination, and will recommend the appropriate tests. They may also offer home testing kits for certain STIs and can notify your sexual partners without revealing your identity.

q: What are some common types of STIs?
a: Some common types of STIs include chlamydia, gonorrhoea, trichomoniasis, genital warts, genital herpes, pubic lice, scabies, syphilis, and human papillomavirus (HPV).

q: How can I prevent getting an STI?
a: You can prevent getting an STI by practicing safe sex, including using condoms and dental dams, getting vaccinated for HPV, and getting tested regularly if you're sexually active.

q: Can STIs be transmitted through oral sex?
i: Is it possible to contract STIs through oral sex?
a: Yes, it is possible to contract STIs through oral sex. It is important to use protection like condoms or dental dams to reduce the risk.

q: What should I do if I test positive for an STI?
a: If you test positive for an STI, it is important to notify your sexual partner and any ex-partners so they can get tested and treated as well. The clinic can assist with this process without revealing your identity if you prefer.

q: Can STIs be cured?
a: Many STIs can be cured with appropriate treatment, but some viral STIs like HIV and genital herpes can be managed but not cured. It is important to get tested and seek treatment if necessary.

q: Do STIs always have symptoms?
a: No, many STIs can be asymptomatic, especially in the early stages. Regular testing is the only way to know for sure if you have an STI.

q: What are some common symptoms of STIs?
a: Common symptoms of STIs include unusual discharge, pain when peeing, lumps or skin growths, rashes, itching, blisters and sores, and warts around the genitals or anus.

q: How can I protect myself from STIs?
a: To protect yourself from STIs, it is important to always practice safe sex by using condoms, getting tested regularly, and knowing your partner's sexual history. Vaccinations are also available for certain STIs like HPV.

q: Can STIs be cured?
a: Many STIs can be cured with proper treatment. However, some viral STIs like HIV and herpes can only be managed with medication to control the symptoms and reduce the risk of transmission.

q: What should I do if I think I have an STI?
a: If you think you have an STI, it is important to go for a check-up at a sexual health clinic as soon as possible. Avoid having sex, including oral sex, without using a condom until you have been properly diagnosed and treated.
